>> You are mistaken. :) It wouldn't require it; I don't mind if both
>> tests fail for the same reason, although I might be concerned if 10
>> tests failed for the same reason. In the latter case, there's a
>> design issue I need to work on.
> 
> 
> Why work on it if the testing framework can do it for you?

Because the framework feature doesn't improve the design of my production
code. Because improving the design has many more - and more important -
advantages than just having less test failures.

Ten tests failing because of one bug isn't the real problem, it's just an
indicator for the real problem - at least if it happens regularly enough
that you care about it. The framework feature doesn't fix the real problem,
it just masks it.

All in my experience - YMMV.

Cheers, Ilja
